lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can correctly form Yes/No questions using the verb “to play”.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Display Yes/No Q&As: “Does he play the cello?” – “Yes, he does.” Students respond using mini whiteboards or thumbs up/down.
stretchStrategies: In teams, students race to complete question–answer chains on the board (e.g., “Does she play the flute?” → “Yes, she does.” → “Does he play the cello?”). Each correct pair adds to the chain, encouraging quick recall and correct form.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and identify the long vowel sounds “a_e” and “i_e”.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say a_e, i_e words aloud. Students listen and sort into two columns. Then they trace and write each word clearly.
stretchStrategies: In teams, students race to complete question–answer chains on the board (e.g., “Does she play the flute?” → “Yes, she does.” → “Does he play the cello?”). Each correct pair adds to the chain, encouraging quick recall and correct form.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise correct answers to Yes/No questions and complete sentence frames (e.g., “___ he play tennis?”) using the correct auxiliary verbs.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Sentence frame: “___ he play tennis?” / “Yes, he ___.” Students complete and then practise Q&A in pairs.

items: Bạn có thích ăn bánh mì không? >> you like eat bread? [do you like to eat bánh mì?]
Con không thích >> I no/not like [I don't like]
Playground words tend to be long and phonetically difficult (slide, see-saw, swings, climbing frame)
Some sports not well known in VN (baseball, cricket, rugby, paragliding, water skiing)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.
